results.title: Rights from the heart. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Therese Descary and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: These seven short animated films from the National Film Board of Canada are united by their inspiration from the 1990 United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. Each film addresses a specific right that was agreed upon by the convention. They are designed to encourage children to think about the world in which they live. They are also inspired by a range of posters from Pierre Post. The films contain no dialogue. “123 Coco” (dir. Pierre M. Trudeau): A young girl struggles in Maths but finally works it out thanks to visualisation. “Papa” (dir. Michele Pauze): The impressions of a young child as they wait for their busy father to play. “T.V. Tango” (dir. Martine Chartrand): A visual illustration of the influence of television on impressionable young minds. “The Orange = L’Orange” (dir: Diane Chartrand): A hungry boy reminisces about a wonderful orange he once had and a thoughtful teacher gives a valuable lesson in acceptance. “Door to door = Porte a porte” (dir: Zabelle Cote): When a class of young children are bullied by the older kids they pool their efforts to get some respect. “A Family for Maria = Une famille pour Maria” (dir. Lina Gagnon): A beggar girl finds herself adopted by a loving family but struggles to forget her past. “To see the world = Voir le monde” (dir: Francine Desbiens): Sleeping on a train a young boy is exposed to the hardships faced by children across the world.

results.title: Rififi a Tokyo = Rififi in Tokyo
results.brief_description:
Following the success of Jules Dassin’s ‘Rififi’, producers decided to exploit the franchise. A number of caper dramas involving a complex robbery were produced in a variety of locations, including Japan. In this particular installment a gang of thieves is planning on taking hold of a single diamond stored in the vaults of a Japanese bank.

Credits: Producer, Jacques Bar ; director, Jacques Deray ; writers, Auguste Le Breton, Jose Giovanni, R. M. Arlaud ; photography, Tadashi Arakami ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Keiko Kishi, Barbara Lass, Karl-Heinz Boehm, Charles Vanel, Hideaki Suzuki, Michel Vitold.

results.title: Rigoletto
results.creator_credit: Carmine Gallone, Giulio Fiaschi, Grandi Film Storici and Excelsa Film
results.brief_description: Film version of Giuseppe Verdi’s tragic opera Rigoletto shot at the Teatro Dell’opera, Rome. This tale of revenge, rape and murder stars the highly acclaimed singer, Tito Gobbi in the role of Rigoletto supported by Mario Filippesche (Duke of Mantua), Anna Maria Canali (Maddalena) and Marcella Govoni acting in the role of Gilda with Lina Pagliughi singing the role of Gilda. Features the Chorus and Orchestra of Teatro Dell’opera, Rome, conducted by Tullio Serafin. Sung in Italian.

results.title: Rights from the heart. Part 3
results.brief_description: These seven short animated films from the National Film Board of Canada are united by their inspiration from the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. Included on the tape are: DUEL; A child who has been brainwashed with censored information to make him a model citizen rebels against all forms of censorship of the mind when he becomes an adult. NARCO BLUES; An ordinary teenager is unwillingly pulled into the harsh world of drugs. However an incident has a salutory effect on him. THE CORA PLAYER; Two young Africans from different social backgrounds defy tradition by falling in love. LOCKED; A boy is seized by an enormous hand that pushes him towards a hazardous lock factory- symobolizing innocence murdered by forced child labour. TRADE; A young Indian girl is sold by her parents to a pimp who takes her to work in a brothel. MASKS; Throughout childhood and adulthood a young man refuses to wear the “masks” imposed on him by social convention. DEATHTRAP; A young man closes all the doors to his heart, but seeing that suicide is a trap, decides to live. In English and French language.

results.title: Riding your bicycle [Junior Road Safety Series Episode 6]
results.creator_credit: Alan Harkness, Kenneth S. Cox, Malcolm Otton, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Kenneth S Cox Productions
results.brief_description: Made in 1971, this training film from the Commonwealth Film Unit is particularly interesting due to the lack of helmets and lycra we see everywhere on the road in 2014. The film teaches people how to ride safely and to try and avoid accidents by showing some examples of cycling gone wrong. Source: NFSA Film Australia Collection.

results.title: Rififi = Du Rififi chez les hommes
results.creator_credit: Jules Dassin, Rene G Vuattoux, Societe Nouvelle Pathe Cinema, Prima Film and Indusfilms
results.brief_description: Rififi is a classic French noir film, an unforgettable crime movie, based on the novel `Du Rififi chez les hommes’, by Auguste Le Breton. American Jules Dassin directed “Rififi” in France, where he was working in exile after being blacklisted in Hollywood. “Rififi” is the tale of Tony, fresh out of prison and looking for his wife (who’s taken up with another man), seeking retribution. Tony is a man of few words but decisive action. He is seduced into joining his old gang for a risky job - a precious jewel robbery to take place in the dead of the night whilst all of Paris sleeps. Tony’s crew consist of old buddies, Jo (Carl Mohner) and Mario (Robert Manual) and an ace safecracker Cesar Le Millanais (played by Dassin himself under the pseudonym Perlo Vita). Characters are well written and are depicted three dimensionally. The band of thieves is shown to have meaningful relationships with the women in their life, and with each other. Thirty -three minutes of the film are devoted to the crime itself - a wordless, almost soundless scene that is the epitome of heist cinema. Dassin won Best Director at Cannes for “Rififi” in 1955. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Riff raff [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Ken Loach, Sally Hibbin, Newvision Films, Channel Four and Parallax Pictures
results.brief_description: Follows the fortunes (and misfortunes) of Stevie, a young labourer fresh out of jail. He soon finds work on a building site, converting an old hospital into luxury apartments. Stevie finds support and fellowship from his fellow workers, a melting pot of men from different parts of England. Conditions on the site are lousy, as well as unsafe, and with no help from the developers, Stevie along with his mates take matters into their own hands.

results.title: Right...said Fred: Fred Schepisi - director
results.creator_credit: Don Featherstone, SBS-TV and Don Featherstone Productions
results.brief_description: Fred Schepisi is one of the most inventive and succcessful film directors Australia has produced. This documentary features in depth interviews with Fred which reveal an articulate, unpretentious, easy going and hardworking filmmaker. The interviews are illustrated with extracts from his movies: The Devil’s Playground, The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith, Barbarosa, The Ice Man, Plenty, Roxanne, Evil Angels, The Russia House, Mr. Baseball and Six Degrees of Separation. This documentary uses a clever mix of interview, reunion with colleagues and excerpts from his films to give a complete impression of a larger than life director and his craft.

results.title: Ride the high country [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Sam Peckinpah, Richard Lyons and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Joel McCrae and Randolph Scott are two ageing cowboys who decide to join up together to safely return a load of gold back from the goldfields to the bank that owns it. However, their motives are widely different: for one it is a chance to prove that he is still capable for work; for the other it is an opportunity to make his fortune and retire. Along the way they pick up a young woman (Mariette Hartley) running away from an abusive father. When her life is threatened their desires and dreams must take second-place to their commitment to the old West’s code of honour. Sam Peckinpah’s beautiful film is an elegy for the old West: for the morality and chivalry that guided the western hero, for the grandeur of the landscape before it was ruined by industry and mining. Using McCrae and Scott as iconic figures from the golden years of Hollywood and contrasting them to the violence represented by the new breed (Warren Oates), Peckinpah’s film also foreshadows the tension between American generations that was to become open confrontation post-Kennedy and post-Vietnam. By the end of the sixties Peckinpah was to completely destroy the western myth in his groundbreaking violent epic “The Wild Bunch”. But “Ride the High Country” is a brief moment of tenderness in the western genre, and McCrae and Scott are the last of the great western heroes. The stunning last moments of this film are an emotionally devastating farewell to American cinema’s most unique genre.

results.title: Riding the Gale
results.creator_credit: Hugh Piper, Genni Batterham, Kim Batterham, Stormbringer Films and Independent Productions (AU)
results.brief_description: In 1978, Genni Batterham contracted Multiple Sclerosis. The battle with this debilitating illness changed the course of Genni’s life and that of her husband, Kim - both individually and as a partnership. This documentary is about Genni’s disability and how she and her husband confronted Multiple Sclerosis and the issues surrounding it.
